<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/63  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 326, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2021

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 682, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the effect of insulation on the cooling of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 468, 120]]<|/det|>
She uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 728, 151]]<|/det|>
The sides of beaker A are covered with material that is a thermal insulator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 437, 182]]<|/det|>
Beaker B has no covering on its sides.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 191, 892, 529]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 549, 144, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 714, 567]]<|/det|>
Record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[546, 580, 920, 599]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\) .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 612, 146, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 612, 920, 644]]<|/det|>
The student pours \(150 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A and records the temperature \(\theta\) at time \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 657, 920, 691]]<|/det|>
She records, in Table 1.1, the temperature of the water in the beaker every 30 s. The student repeats the process for beaker B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 704, 539, 722]]<|/det|>
Add units to the column headings in Table 1.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 704, 920, 722]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 42, 470, 58]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 73, 541, 89]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 102, 811, 361]]<|/det|>
beaker A with insulationbeaker B without insulation
\(t/\)\(\theta /\)\(\theta /\)

6084.581.5
9083.580.0
12082.579.0
15082.078.5
18081.578.0

Justify your answer by reference to values from the results. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 705, 920, 723]]<|/det|> [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 180, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use the readings for beaker B from Table 1.1 and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 106, 556, 134]]<|/det|>
\[x_{1} = \frac{\theta_{0} - \theta_{90}}{T},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 135, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 183, 329, 201]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 259, 920, 280]]<|/det|>
<form>X_1 = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 291, 181, 308]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 291, 920, 324]]<|/det|>
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the second half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use the readings for beaker B from Table 1.1 and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[433, 325, 564, 354]]<|/det|>
\[x_{2} = \frac{\theta_{90} - \theta_{180}}{T},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 355, 920, 389]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 402, 329, 420]]<|/det|>
Include the unit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 478, 920, 497]]<|/det|>
<form>X_2 = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 635, 920, 685]]<|/det|>
The student sets the distance \(u\) between the triangular object and the lens to \(20.0 \text{cm}\). He moves the screen until a sharp image of the triangular object is seen on the screen. The student measures, and records in Table 3.1, the height \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\) of the image on the screen.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 696, 920, 730]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 774, 920, 792]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 579, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the strength of an electromagnet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
The electromagnet is made from a coil of insulated wire wrapped around an iron rod. When there is an electric current in the coil, the iron rod becomes magnetised. The electromagnet can then attract magnetic materials (e.g. iron and steel).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how **one** factor affects the number of steel paper clips the electromagnet can support.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 212, 398, 228]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 228, 452, 244]]<|/det|>
· an electromagnet, shown in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 285, 259]]<|/det|>
· a power supply

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 258, 413, 274]]<|/det|>
· a selection of steel paper clips.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 324, 305]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 156, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>•</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 319, 806, 336]]<|/det|>
state a factor which can be measured and list any additional apparatus needed

<label>•</label>

Every reasonable effort has been made by the publisher (UCLES) to trace copyright holders, but if any items requiring clearance have unwittingly been included, the publisher will be pleased to make amends at the earliest possible opportunity.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 870, 917, 905]]<|/det|>
To avoid the issue of disclosure of answer- related information to candidates, all copyright acknowledgements are reproduced online in the Cambridge Assessment International Education Copyright Acknowledgements Booklet. This is produced for each series of examinations and is freely available to download at www.cambridgeinternational.org after the live examination series.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 913, 917, 937]]<|/det|>
Cambridge Assessment International Education is part of the Cambridge Assessment Group. Cambridge Assessment is the brand name of the University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate (UCLES), which itself is a department of the University of Cambridge.
